By Mark Hosenball and Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Leading Democrats are growing increasingly worried that the hackers who made public leaked documents this week were trying  to sabotage the Democratic candidates in several central Florida congressional races
column2: the first time such leaks have been targeted so directly.Two sources familiar with Democratic Party investigations of  recent cyber attacks said documents made public this week by the hacker known as Guccifer2 contained information that could damage Democratic candidates in competitive Florida contests for the U.S. House of Representatives.The documents
column3: hacked from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC)
column4: which raises funds for the party's House candidates
column5: are detailed dossiers describing the Florida candidates' backgrounds
column6: including personal details
column7: as well as political
column8: economic and demographic profiles of the strategic congressional districts.

column1: Since 1996
column2: the parties winning the counties in the Interstate 4 corridor between Orlando and Tampa
column3: where several of the targeted districts are located
column4: have won the presidency.Many of the state's moderate swing voters live in the I-4 corridor
column5: and if Republican voters there turn out in force
column6: it could cut into the vote for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton.The DCCC was one of several Democratic Party organizations
column7: including the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign
column9: but the Democratic Party sources said they did not know who might have helped the hackers select the Florida races to target
column10: or what the hackers were trying to accomplish.

column1: There is
column2: though
column3: a growing pattern of attacks on the data systems of U.S. political organizations by hackers whom U.S. intelligence officials and private cyber security firms have concluded are working for or with Russian intelligence agencies.

column1: Donald Trump's presidential campaign has hired consultants CrowdStrike to bolster its data security. But two people familiar with attempts to breach the campaign and other Republican organizations said that so far there was no indication of a penetration as serious as those of the Democratic organizations
column2: and CrowdStrike is not investigating any successful hacking of Trump campaign data. (Reporting By Mark Hosenball and Ginger Gibson.; Editing by John Walcott and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Clinton'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-lawsuit-idUSKCN10U26F	Clinton need not give sworn testimony over emails: U.S. judge	"
By Jonathan Allen
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Democratic Party presidential candidate Hillary Clinton does not need to give sworn testimony in a lawsuit brought by a conservative watchdog group over her use of an unauthorized private email system while she was U.S. secretary of state
column2: a judge ruled on Friday.Clinton must instead respond in writing within 30 days to questions submitted by Judicial Watch
column3: a group that has long been critical of her conduct and which is suing the Department of State over Clinton-era records.Judge Emmet Sullivan's ruling in U.S. District Court in Washington is likely to be a relief to Democrats
column4: who did not welcome the prospect of Clinton having to submit to hours of questioning by lawyers in the middle of her campaign for the Nov. 8 election against Republican Party candidate Donald Trump. Clinton
column5: who served as the country's top diplomat from 2009 to 2013
column6: has apologized for her decision to use the unorthodox email set-up
column7: which had the effect of shielding her communications from public-records laws until the arrangement came to light last year.Voters have said in opinion polls that the email server issue contributes to impressions that Clinton is untrustworthy. The U.S. Department of Justice concluded last month there were no grounds to prosecute Clinton for the arrangement following a year-long investigation.

column1: Sullivan has allowed Judicial Watch to obtain sworn testimony in sometimes testy exchanges with several Clinton aides in recent months
column2: saying the court needs to establish whether the server was set up to thwart the Freedom of Information Act. But the judge agreed with Clinton's lawyers that former high-ranking government officials can be ordered to give sworn testimony only in ""exceptional circumstances.""

column1: Sullivan also allowed Judicial Watch to get sworn testimony from a former State Department official named John Bentel. According to a scathing report by the State Department's inspector general
column2: Bentel
column3: then a technology official in Clinton's office
column4: told junior staffers to never speak of Clinton's email server again after they raised concerns. Bentel and his lawyer have declined to comment on the episode.A spokesman for Clinton could not immediately be reached for comment on Friday.

column1: Judicial Watch said it was happy with the ruling.""We will move quickly to get these answers
column2: Tom Fitton
column3: the group's president
column4: said in a statement. ""The decision is a reminder that Hillary Clinton is not above the law."" (Reporting by Jonathan Allen
column5: additional reporting by Luciana Lopez; editing by Grant McCool)"	['Sullivan'

Last year

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN10U1YI	Clinton leads Trump by eight points: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton leads Republican rival Donald Trump by 8 percentage points among likely voters
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll released on Friday.The Aug. 14-18 survey showed 42 percent of Americans supported Clinton ahead of the Nov. 8 general election. That compares with 34 percent support for Trump. Another 23 percent of likely voters would not pick either candidate. Clinton has led Trump in the poll throughout most of the 2016 campaign
column3: and has maintained her advantage following last month's Republican and Democratic conventions. Since late July
column4: support for the former secretary of state has ranged between 41 percent and 44 percent of likely voters
column5: while Trump's support has varied between 33 percent and 39 percent.The race was tighter at this point in the 2012 election
column6: with Democratic President Barack Obama ahead of Republican nominee Mitt Romney by less than 2 percentage points.

column1: Clinton also led a separate Reuters/Ipsos poll that asked people to choose between Clinton
column2: Trump
column3: Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson and Jill Stein of the Green Party. Some 41 percent supported Clinton and 34 percent supported Trump. Among alternative-party candidates
column4: Johnson came in third with 7 percent and about 2 percent supported Stein. Clinton and Trump have both struggled to inspire American voters this year. According to the poll
column5: neither candidate is regarded favorably by most Americans
column6: and two-thirds of U.S. adults believe the country is on the wrong track.

column1: Clinton continues to face questions about her handling of classified emails while serving as Obama's secretary of state
column2: while Trump's off-the-cuff remarks about immigrants
column3: women and Muslims have rankled members of his own party.Republican leaders
column4: including former members of Congress
column5: have called for the Republican National Committee to stop helping Trump and refocus its resources on helping candidates win down-ballot races for the House of Representatives and the Senate. Earlier this week
column6: Trump reshuffled his campaign leadership while his campaign chief
column7: Paul Manafort
column8: faced increased scrutiny over his work with pro-Russian political groups in the Ukraine. Manafort resigned on Friday.

column1: The Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted online in English in all 50 states. It surveyed samples of 1
column2: 119 and 1
column3: 118 likely voters
column4: respectively
column5: and has a credibility interval
column6: a measure of accuracy
column7: of 3 percentage points. (Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Romney'

NEW YORK An artists' collective took credit for exposing Donald Trump to unflattering scrutiny on Thursday
column2: saying it was responsible for a life-sized nude statue of the Republican presidential candidate that turned up in a New York City park.      Copies of the orange-tinted likeness - featuring a massive belly

column4: the unauthorized installation appeared to surprise passers-by - prompting stares

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ukraine-manafort-idUSKCN10U10F	Ukrainian MP offers more details on alleged payments to Trump campaign chief	"
By Pavel Polityuk
| KIEV

KIEV A Ukrainian lawmaker on Friday divulged more details of what he said were payments made to Donald Trump's campaign chief in the U.S. presidential race by the political party of the Kremlin-backed former Ukrainian leader Viktor Yanukovich.MP Serhiy Leshchenko said money was allocated for Trump aide Paul Manafort to finance services such as carrying out exit polls at elections
column2: buying computers and conducting research. The largest single payment was $3.5 million. Manafort has denied allegations - first made in the New York Times on Monday - that he received cash payments worth more than $12 million over five years that were itemized on secret ledgers belonging to Yanukovich's Party of Regions. Ukrainian anti-corruption investigators have corroborated the existence of what they called a ""black ledger"" of payments made by Yanukovich's party but stressed that they could not establish whether Manafort himself received money.Leshchenko
column3: a member of President Petro Poroshenko's parliamentary faction
column4: called on Ukrainian authorities to send a request for assistance to Washington to investigate Manafort.

column1: Manafort didn't work for free in Ukraine
column2: he served the Party of Regions for over 10 years and it is clear that his work was paid
column3: Leshchenko told a news conference.""The money was transferred in cash and it is impossible to trace the transactions
column4: but I have no doubt as to the authenticity of these documents
column5: he said.

column1: If Mr Manafort denies any allegations
column2: I think he has to be interrogated into this case and prove his position that he was not involved
column3: Leshchenko added. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's campaign has previously said the allegations were evidence of ""more troubling connections between Donald Trump's team and pro-Kremlin elements in Ukraine"".Trump
column4: a Republican
column5: has spoken favorably in the past of Russian President Vladimir Putin. Last month
column6: he invited Russian hackers to find ""missing"" emails from Clinton's time as secretary of state
column7: when she used a private email server to conduct government business
column8: although he later described that call as sarcasm.

column1: In response to the earlier report in the New York Times
column2: Manafort denied any impropriety in a statement on Monday. ""I have never received a single 'off-the-books cash payment' as falsely 'reported' by The New York Times
column3: nor have I ever done work for the governments of Ukraine or Russia
column4: he said.Trump overhauled his top political team this week
column5: demoting Manafort
column6: who was brought on as campaign chief in June to professionalize its approach but struggled to get the wealthy businessman to rein in his freewheeling ways. (Writing by Matthias Williams; editing by Mark Heinrich)"	['Paul'

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN10T1MB	Trump says he regrets past remarks that 'caused personal pain'	"

| CHARLOTTE

column1: CHARLOTTE

column5: in this sense.""Trump has so far been unable to extend his appeal beyond white middle-class voters who pack his rallies. Conway said her rise to campaign manager showed Trump valued a more policy-driven approach that would appeal to women and independent voters.""The way to speak to women and all Americans is through issues. We've got to get away from this content-free campaign and on to the substance
column6: she said.    The campaign will put two ads on the air in five states this week

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-fbi-idUSKCN10U0FK	Clinton told FBI Colin Powell suggested she use private email: NYT	"
WASHINGTON Democratic U.S. presidential nominee Hillary Clinton told federal investigators that former Secretary of State Colin Powell suggested she use a personal email account
column2: the New York Times reported late on Thursday.Clinton has for over a year been dogged by questions about her use of a private email account while she was the nation's top diplomat.The newspaper said the information came from notes the Federal Bureau of Investigation delivered to Congress on Tuesday
column3: which contained details from a more than three hour interview the agency conducted with Clinton over her private email use.The Times also cited an upcoming book that described a dinner conversation where Powell told Clinton to use her own email except for classified information. The newspaper also reported that Clinton asked Powell in a 2009 email exchange about his use of email while serving under former president George W. Bush.Reuters could not independently verify the report. Representatives for Clinton could not be immediately reached late on Thursday.

column1: Colin Powell's office in a statement said he could not recall the dinner conversation. He did recall describing the system he used to her
column2: but the statement did not say he suggested Clinton do the same. ""He did write former Secretary Clinton an email memo describing his use of his personal AOL email account for unclassified messages and how it vastly improved communications within the State Department
column3: the statement said. ""At the time there was no equivalent system within the department.""

column1: He used a secure department computer to manage classified information
column2: the statement said. Powell has said he had no choice besides using his private account as the department did not have a fully functioning email system of its own when he joined in 2001.

column1: Republicans have repeatedly hammered Clinton over the issue
column2: helping to drive opinion poll results showing that many U.S. voters doubt her trustworthiness.FBI Director James Comey announced last month that no criminal charges would be filed over Clinton's use of private email servers while secretary of state
column3: but rebuked her for ""extremely careless"" handling of classified information. (Reporting by John Walcott in Washington
column4: Curtis Skinner in San Francisco
column5: and Jonathan Allen in New York; Editing by Nick Macfie)"	['Allen'

column1: WASHINGTON The Clinton Foundation will stop accepting foreign and corporate donations if Hillary Clinton is elected president and will stop holding the annual Clinton Global Initiative meetings whatever the outcome of the November election
column2: a foundation spokesman said on Thursday.Former President Bill Clinton told staff members on Thursday he would resign from the foundation's board and that it would only accept donations from U.S. citizens and independent charities.The former president also said he would hold the 12th and final Clinton Global Initiative in September. The annual meetings have included current and former heads of state
column3: corporate leaders and celebrities who discussed poverty
column4: healthcare
column5: development and other issues.    Foundation spokesman Craig Minassian confirmed the moves
column6: which were first reported by the Associated Press.

column1: The foundation has come under fire during Hillary Clinton's Democratic presidential campaign
column2: with Republicans charging that donors were rewarded with access to her and her aides as well as her husband while she was secretary of state from 2009 to 2013. Other critics have said the foundation's reliance on millions of dollars from foreign governments created conflicts of interest for a would-be U.S. president.

column1: Clinton resigned from the foundation's board after launching her successful bid for the Democratic presidential nomination. She will face Republican Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election. The Bill
column2: Hillary & Chelsea Clinton Foundation
column3: founded in 2001
column4: has raised more than $2 billion for causes that focus on health and environmental issues
